key_insight: Prune irrelevant visual tokens using text-driven relevance before temporal reasoning in SAM2, cutting compute and memory cost while preserving segmentation quality.
problem_solved: SAM2's prompt-driven video object segmentation is bottlenecked by propagating dense visual tokens across time, causing high computational and memory demands that limit scalability and real-time deployment.
method: Compute text-conditioned relevance scores for visual tokens (cross-modal similarity between prompt text and image tokens).
Prune low-relevance tokens early and only propagate a sparse subset into downstream temporal reasoning modules.
Use adaptive thresholds and lightweight token recovery mechanisms to retain segmentation accuracy while enabling hardware-friendly sparse processing.
impact: Significantly lowers latency and memory footprint for video segmentation pipelines built on SAM2, making prompt-driven video understanding more practical for real-world and resource-constrained deployments.
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram: image encoder → text-conditioned relevance map → token pruning → temporal module (showing reduced token count).
Heatmap overlay on video frames showing token relevance scores derived from the text prompt.
Bar chart comparing compute (FLOPs), memory, and latency for baseline SAM2 vs. Fast SAM2 with pruning.
Side-by-side qualitative frames: baseline vs. pruned-token segmentation to illustrate minimal quality loss.
paper_title: Fast SAM2 with Text-Driven Token Pruning
paper_authors: Avilasha Mandal, Chaoning Zhang, Fachrina Dewi Puspitasari, Xudong Wang, Jiaquan Zhang
